entry.title: Newsletter #110
entry.content:
Hi There!

This week we got a new ping pong table woo hoo! The guys were happy to try their ping pong skills.

Below you can find the usual list of interesting articles we discovered in the past 7 days.

  • [sydphp] http2 and asynchronous apis // speaker deck

  • amazon inspector – automated security assessment service | aws official blog

  • amazon rds update – mariadb is now available | aws official blog

  • amazon web services to add analytics – wsj

  • containing your logical backups: mydumper in docker

  • css polyfills from the future

  • developing with docker at ifttt

  • easiest way to setup ubuntu as a vpn server – ask ubuntu

  • finding a video poker bug made these guys rich—then vegas made them pay

  • getting started with raygun: insights and crash reporting for app developers – tuts code tutorial

  • how to monitor docker-based applications using new relic – tuts code tutorial

  • how to name things: the hardest problem in programming

  • integrating web components with angularjs · pascal precht

  • json-schema faker

  • linux kernel dev sarah sharp quits, citing ‘brutal’ communications style | network world

  • my first 12 years at amazon.com – jeff barr’s blog

  • no comments allowed on reddit’s new news site ‘upvoted’ | wired

  • not awesome: es6 classes

  • optimizing android bytecode with redex | engineering blog | facebook code

  • programming sucks

  • rasmus lerdorf – speeding up the web with php 7

  • react reflux and how to boost your development workflow // speaker deck

  • refactoring to a happier development team – interview with coraline ada ehmke – fog creek blog

  • remote-first vs. remote-friendly

  • rocket internet expects start-ups to break even soon | reuters

  • runnable documentation: code for humans – github engineering

  • sysdig cloud | announcing microservice-level monitoring for ecs

  • tcp over ip anycast – pipe dream or reality? | linkedin engineering

  • testing required, tdd optional | stitch fix technology – multithreaded

  • the debate around “do we even need css anymore?” | css-tricks

  • the debate around “do we even need css anymore?” | css-tricks

  • understanding css: selector specificity — medium

entry.title: Newsletter #66
entry.content:
Hey folks from the software engineering community!

It’s #TechThursday at #namshi!

Our comrade Alex is at SymfonyCon Madrid with an awesome and super exciting talk about angular.

Next week, Oba, Lucio and Alex will be at the super exciting Docker Eu Conference to collect some thoughts about the newest technologies.

Here is the list with awesome links to keep you busy during the week:

  • SERIOUS CONFUSION with Resource Timing

  • What’s in a Function Name?

  • The Real Cost of Slow Time vs Downtime

  • Microsoft brings Docker CLI to Windows

  • Rocket Internet-Backed Jumia Raises $150M For Its African E-Commerce Business

  • What is product design?

  • An interactive guide for exploring various important properties of the package.json for node.js apps

  • A Programmer Describes How He Nearly Went Insane Learning To Code

  • Codewars, improve your programming skills

  • React Tube Tracker – a simple application to check the predicted arrival times of trains at stations on the London Underground network built with React.

  • Yahoo! Mail moving to React

  • Docker vs VMs

  • Create your own Docker image

  • Service discovery with consul and consul-template

  • Building a complete Tweet index

  • VclFiddle is an online tool for experimenting with the Varnish Cache HTTP reverse-proxy

  • Sometimes Kill -9 Isn’t Enough

  • Performance Tuning EC2 Instances

  • Web-based PostgreSQL database browser

  • Go and JSON

  • Aurora on Amazon RDS

  • AWS Public IP Address Ranges Now Available in JSON Form

  • Which configuration management tool should you use?

  • A Saltstack salt-api and reactor formula for integrating HTTP webhooks with Saltstack executions

  • Jenkins: saltstack-plugin

  • Docker Security Flaw Found

  • Rackspace Page Load Speed checker

  • Auditing systemd: solving failed units with systemctl

  • Best Practices For Scaling Elasticsearch In The Cloud

  • Working with Elasticsearch

  • How we built the new BBC Homepage

  • wallaby.js runs your code when you write it

  • conveyor-belt

  • How the Node Foundation will Unify Node.js with io.js

  • Programm a virtual robot which moves in a 3D

  • npm subreddit

entry.title: Newsletter #44
entry.content:
TechThursday is here folks and we have two special mentions today.

Mohamad Hallal wrote an awesome post about his pitfalls as junior developer

Lucio released a very cool personal project: Carmen Sandiego. This nodejs app let’s you visualize your Foursquare checkins on a world map! Check the dedicated blog post

Here the list of other useful links of the week:

  • Introducing Ampersand.js, a highly modular, loosely coupled, non-frameworky framework for building advanced JavaScript apps

  • On the death of Map-Reduce at Google

  • Handling errors in asynchronous flow

  • Javascript implementation of common data structures

  • A functional reactive language for interactive applications

  • Passwords in Plain text

  • Google Web Started Kit

  • Recovering deleted files using only grep

  • Benefits of post-mortems for incidents, the need to make them blameless – and the knock on effect that has on an organisation’s culture

  • Why it’s important to have real users, in this case systems administrators, on the product team

  • A Short List of DevOps Tools

  • Should Everyone Learn to Code?

  • Gaufrette: a PHP library that provides a filesystem abstraction layer

  • Bring High Performance Into Your PHP App

  • Random tricks when using AngularJS

  • Long Term Web Semantics

  • Google’s New Web Starter Kit Is A Boilerplate For Multi-Screen Web Development

  • Find out about the latest product and platform innovations at Google I/O 2014

  • Quick Tip: set relative URLs with the “base” Tag

  • Refactoring Legacy Code: Part 6 – Attacking Complex Methods

  • RESTing with Symfony 2

  • Code for maintainability so the next developer doesn’t hate you

  • Docker: How speed up deployment involving npm install and bower install

entry.title: Newsletter #43
entry.content:
TechThursday is here again!

This week we released a new and opensource library on github: Mockserver for mocking apis, our fellow Mohamad wrote a post about it, check it!

  • Wavepot… just check and have fun with it!

  • Changelog, a tool designed to answer the question “What changed in the last twenty minutes?” trough a simple HTTP api and a web interface

  • How we decreased sign up confirmation email bounces by 50%

  • Domain Driven Design principles with Symfony2

  • Symfony2: How to create framework independent controllers?

  • Symfony2: value of HttpFoundation

  • Stateless services

  • Your Job is not to code – different perspective – Your job is to code

  • Docker for your dev environment

  • 7 Web design disasters that drive people crazy

  • Lightweight and flexible command-line JSON Processor

  • Ember Tutorial

  • Everything you need to know about cryptography in one hour

  • MockServer, effortless API mocking library in Nodejs

  • Tesla drops all their patents

  • Deis: Your PaaS, your rules.

  • Flynn Vs Deis, two Docker-related open source projects compared

  • Top 10 Docker Tools

  • CoreOs: Linux for Massive Server Deployments

  • 12 factors apps in plain english

  • A nice set of strong cipher settings for Apache, Nginx and Lighttpd. A good case study.

  • Checkzilla, a simple tool for letting you know about out-of-date software versions
